unit_title: Resistance and Resistivity: Ohm's Law and Material Properties
subject: AP Physics C: Electricity & Magnetism
expanded_description: This unit explores the fundamental relationship between electric field and current density through Ohm's law, examining how material properties like resistivity and conductivity determine resistance in various geometries. Students will learn to calculate resistance for complex shapes, understand temperature dependence, and analyze non-ohmic materials.
learning_objectives: Apply Ohm's law in both microscopic and macroscopic forms
Calculate resistance for various conductor geometries
Relate resistivity to material properties and temperature
Analyze series and parallel resistor combinations
Solve problems involving non-uniform resistivity distributions
Design simple resistive circuits to meet specifications
prerequisites: Understanding of current and current density (Unit 3.1)
Knowledge of electric field and potential relationships
Understanding of conservation laws in physics

core_concept.principle: Ohm's Law, Resistivity, Conductivity, Resistance Calculation, Material Properties
core_concept.explanation: Ohm's law establishes the fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in macroscopic form (V=IR) and between electric field and current density in microscopic form (J=σE). Resistivity is an intrinsic material property that depends on temperature and material composition, while resistance depends on both resistivity and geometric factors.

image.caption: Relationship between material properties and geometric factors in resistance

sections.introduction: This section establishes the mathematical foundation for resistance and resistivity, exploring Ohm's law in both macroscopic and microscopic forms, and examining how material properties and geometry combine to determine resistance.

key_concept.definition: Ohm's Law, Resistivity, Conductivity, Resistance Geometry, Temperature Dependence
key_concept.context: Resistance quantifies how strongly a material opposes electric current flow, while resistivity is an intrinsic property independent of geometry. Ohm's law describes linear current-voltage relationships in many materials, though many real materials exhibit non-ohmic behavior under certain conditions. Temperature significantly affects resistivity through changes in carrier concentration and scattering mechanisms.

image.caption: Microscopic and macroscopic forms of Ohm's law

classifications.value: Categorization based on electrical conduction properties
characteristics: Conductors: low resistivity (10⁻⁸ to 10⁻⁵ Ω·m), metallic bonding
Semiconductors: intermediate resistivity (10⁻⁵ to 10⁶ Ω·m), tunable properties
Insulators: high resistivity (10⁶ to 10¹⁸ Ω·m), minimal free charges
Superconductors: zero resistivity below critical temperature
Non-ohmic materials: resistivity depends on field or current
Anisotropic materials: resistivity depends on direction
classifications.behavior: Different material classes exhibit distinct conduction mechanisms. Conductors follow Ohm's law with positive temperature coefficient. Semiconductors have negative temperature coefficient. Insulators have very high but temperature-dependent resistivity. Superconductors exhibit zero resistance and Meissner effect. Non-ohmic materials show voltage-dependent resistance. Anisotropic materials have direction-dependent conductivity.

Electron and hole transport with temperature-activated carrier generation

classifications.note: The distinction between ohmic and non-ohmic behavior depends on both material properties and operating conditions

principles.statement: Macroscopic Ohm's Law: V = IR, where R is resistance in ohms (Ω). Microscopic Ohm's Law: J = σE, where σ is conductivity. Resistivity Definition: ρ = 1/σ, intrinsic material property. Resistance Calculation: R = ρL/A for uniform conductor, generalized to R = ∫ρ dl/A for non-uniform cases. Temperature Dependence: ρ(T) = ρ₀[1 + α(T - T₀)] for metals (positive α). ρ(T) = ρ₀e^(E_g/kT) for intrinsic semiconductors (negative α). Series Resistance: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + ... + R_n. Parallel Resistance: 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ... + 1/R_n. Power Dissipation: P = IV = I²R = V²/R (Joule heating). Non-ohmic Devices: Diodes, transistors, varistors with nonlinear I-V characteristics. Breakdown Effects: Avalanche, Zener breakdown at high fields.
principles.application: Calculate resistance from material properties and geometry. Determine resistivity from resistance measurements. Analyze temperature effects on resistance. Solve series and parallel resistor networks. Calculate power dissipation in resistive elements. Design simple resistive circuits.
principles.example: Resistance of cylindrical wire. Temperature coefficient calculation. Series-parallel resistor combinations. Non-ohmic device characterization.
principles.analogy: Electrical resistance is like water flow through pipes. 'Resistivity' is the 'pipe material roughness'—intrinsic to the material. 'Resistance' is the overall 'flow opposition' combining 'roughness' and 'pipe geometry'. A 'long narrow pipe' (high L/A) has high 'flow resistance'. 'Series pipes' add their 'resistances'. 'Parallel pipes' provide alternative 'flow paths'. 'Temperature effects' are like changing 'water viscosity' with temperature. 'Non-ohmic behavior' is like 'valves' that change 'resistance' with 'flow rate'. 'Power dissipation' is the 'frictional heating' from 'flow resistance'.

worked_examples.title: Resistance of Copper Wire
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the resistance of a 100 m long copper wire with diameter 2 mm at 20°C. Copper resistivity ρ = 1.68×10⁻⁸ Ω·m at 20°C. If the temperature rises to 80°C (α = 0.00393/°C), find the new resistance.

step_by_step.explanation: Significant resistance increase affects power transmission efficiency and voltage drop

worked_examples.final_answer: R₂₀ = 0.535 Ω, R₈₀ = 0.661 Ω. 23.6% increase due to temperature rise.

image.caption: Copper wire resistance calculation with temperature effects

worked_examples.title: Non-Uniform Resistivity Rod
worked_examples.problem: A cylindrical rod of length L and cross-sectional area A has resistivity that varies linearly from ρ₁ at end A to ρ₂ at end B. Find the total resistance.

step_by_step.explanation: ρ(x) = ρ₁ + (ρ₂ - ρ₁)(x/L), where x=0 at end A, x=L at end B
Resistance equals that of uniform rod with average resistivity (ρ₁ + ρ₂)/2

worked_examples.final_answer: R = (L/A)[(ρ₁ + ρ₂)/2]. The resistance depends on the average resistivity.

image.caption: Resistance calculation for rod with linearly varying resistivity

worked_examples.title: Series-Parallel Resistor Network
worked_examples.problem: Find the equivalent resistance between points A and B for the network: R₁=10Ω and R₂=20Ω in series, this combination in parallel with R₃=30Ω, and this combination in series with R₄=40Ω.

step_by_step.explanation: Check: Current division and voltage distribution consistent with equivalent resistance

worked_examples.final_answer: R_AB = 55 Ω. The network reduces to a single equivalent resistance.

image.caption: Equivalent resistance calculation for series-parallel network

sections.introduction: This section explores complex resistance calculations for non-standard geometries, non-ohmic materials, and practical applications where resistance plays a critical role in circuit behavior and design.

key_concept.definition: Non-Standard Geometries, Contact Resistance, Non-Ohmic Behavior, Sheet Resistance, Practical Applications
key_concept.context: Real-world resistance problems often involve complex geometries that cannot be solved with simple R=ρL/A formulas, non-ohmic materials where resistance changes with operating conditions, and practical considerations like contact resistance and distributed resistance effects. Understanding these advanced concepts is essential for circuit design and analysis.

classifications.value: Categories of complex resistance calculations and applications
characteristics: Non-prismatic conductors: varying cross-sections along length
Contact resistance: interface effects in connections
Sheet resistance: thin-film and 2D material applications
Frequency-dependent resistance: skin and proximity effects
classifications.behavior: Different advanced problems require specialized approaches. Non-prismatic conductors need integration. Distributed resistance requires field analysis. Non-ohmic devices need characteristic curves. Contact resistance depends on surface properties. Sheet resistance uses square counting. Frequency effects involve electromagnetic theory.

principles.statement: General Resistance Formula: R = ∫(ρ dl/A) for current along path element dl. Non-Prismatic Conductors: Integration required for tapered, curved, or variable cross-section conductors. Contact Resistance: R_contact = ρ_c/A, where ρ_c is specific contact resistivity. Arises from surface oxides, contamination, limited contact area. Sheet Resistance: R_sheet = ρ/t for thin films, units Ω/□ (ohms per square). Resistance = R_sheet × (L/W) where L/W is number of squares. Non-Ohmic Devices: Diode: I = I₀(e^(V/nV_T) - 1). Varistor: I ∝ V^α. Thermistor: R(T) = R₀e^(β(1/T - 1/T₀)). Frequency Effects: Skin depth δ = √(2/ωμσ), effective resistance increases with frequency. Distributed RC Effects: Transmission line behavior at high frequencies. Practical Considerations: Power rating and derating. Temperature management. Tolerance and stability. Aging and reliability.
principles.application: Calculate resistance for complex geometries using integration. Analyze contact resistance in interconnections. Apply sheet resistance concept to thin films. Characterize non-ohmic device behavior. Design resistors for specific applications. Account for frequency-dependent resistance effects.
principles.example: Resistance of tapered conductor. Contact resistance in semiconductor devices. Thin-film resistor design. Diode circuit analysis.
principles.analogy: Advanced resistance is like complex plumbing systems. 'Non-prismatic conductors' are like 'tapered pipes' requiring flow integration. 'Contact resistance' is like 'poor pipe joints' causing extra pressure drops. 'Sheet resistance' is like 'flow through thin layers' where only shape matters. 'Non-ohmic devices' are like 'check valves' with directional flow properties. 'Frequency effects' are like 'water hammer' phenomena at high flow rates. 'Distributed resistance' is like 'long garden hoses' with pressure drop all along their length. Practical design requires considering all these 'plumbing complexities' simultaneously.

worked_examples.title: Resistance of Truncated Cone
worked_examples.problem: A truncated conical conductor has end radii a and b (a < b), length L, resistivity ρ. Current flows axially. Find the resistance.

step_by_step.explanation: r(x) = a + (b - a)(x/L), where x=0 at small end, x=L at large end
dR = ρ dx/A(x) = ρ dx/{π[a + (b - a)(x/L)]²}
R = ∫₀ᴸ ρ dx/{π[a + (b - a)(x/L)]²} = (ρ/π)∫₀ᴸ dx/[a + (b - a)(x/L)]²
Let u = a + (b - a)(x/L), then du = (b - a)dx/L, dx = L du/(b - a)
When x=0, u=a; when x=L, u=b
R = (ρ/π)∫ₐᵇ [L/(b - a)] du/u² = (ρL/π(b - a))∫ₐᵇ u⁻² du = (ρL/π(b - a))[-1/u]ₐᵇ

worked_examples.final_answer: R = ρL/(πab). Resistance depends on geometric mean of end areas.

image.caption: Resistance calculation for truncated conical conductor

worked_examples.title: Sheet Resistance Application
worked_examples.problem: A thin-film resistor is made from a material with ρ = 10⁻⁵ Ω·m, thickness t = 1 μm. The resistor pattern is 100 μm wide, 500 μm long. Calculate the sheet resistance and total resistance.

step_by_step.explanation: Sheet resistance concept simplifies thin-film resistor design—only shape ratio matters, not absolute size

worked_examples.final_answer: R_sheet = 10 Ω/□, R_total = 50 Ω. The resistor has 5 squares of 10 Ω/□ material.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Sheet resistance and thin-film resistor design

image.caption: Thin-film resistor geometry and square counting

worked_examples.title: Diode Resistance Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A silicon diode has I = I₀(e^(V/V_T) - 1) with I₀ = 10⁻¹² A, V_T = 25 mV. Find the dynamic resistance at (a) V = 0.6 V, (b) V = 0.7 V.

step_by_step.explanation: Dynamic resistance decreases exponentially with voltage—highly non-ohmic behavior

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) r_d = 0.943 Ω at 0.6 V, (b) r_d = 0.0172 Ω at 0.7 V. Resistance decreases dramatically with small voltage increase.

image.caption: Dynamic resistance variation in semiconductor diode

worked_examples.title: Contact Resistance Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A silicon device has aluminum contacts with specific contact resistivity ρ_c = 10⁻⁶ Ω·cm². If the contact area is 10 μm × 10 μm, find the contact resistance. If current is 10 mA, find the voltage drop across the contact.

step_by_step.explanation: 10 mV drop may be significant in low-voltage circuits. Smaller contacts have higher resistance.
As device dimensions shrink, contact resistance becomes increasingly important

worked_examples.final_answer: R_contact = 1 Ω, V_drop = 10 mV. Contact resistance is significant for small contact areas.

common_misconceptions: Thinking resistance depends only on material, not geometry
Believing all materials follow Ohm's law
Thinking series resistors always increase resistance
Believing parallel resistors always decrease resistance
Assuming resistance is constant with temperature
real_world_applications: Electrical wire sizing for building wiring
Power resistor selection for electronic circuits
summary: This unit has comprehensively explored resistance and resistivity, establishing the fundamental relationships described by Ohm's law and extending to complex geometries and non-ohmic materials. Through the analysis of temperature effects, series-parallel combinations, non-standard geometries, sheet resistance, contact resistance, and non-ohmic devices, students have developed the ability to analyze and design resistive elements for diverse applications. The distinction between material properties (resistivity) and device properties (resistance), along with practical considerations for real-world applications, provides a solid foundation for circuit analysis and design across electrical engineering domains.
